docs.lead_paragraph: With The Republican battle over tax cuts escalating daily, Senator John McCain demanded today that Gov. George W. Bush stop running a commercial attacking his tax cut plan, while Bush advisers visited McCain headquarters to scrutinize his tax calculations. Those were the highlights of a campaign day that veered from the serious to the surreal to the silly.

headline.main: McCain and Bush Find a Fight in the Details of a Tax Cut

docs.abstract: Sen John McCain demands that Gov George W Bush stop running a commercial that says proposal in McCain's tax cut plan to repeal tax exemptions for certain employer-provided fringe benefits would raise taxes by $40 billion and hurt working people; two of Bush's tax advisers travel to McCain's national campaign headquarters to scrutinize his tax calcuations; race between Bush and McCain has come down to taxes, and there are large ideological differences behind their competing tax-cut policies; photo (M)
docs.snippet: With The Republican battle over tax cuts escalating daily, Senator John McCain demanded today that Gov. George W. Bush stop running a commercial attacking his tax cut plan, while Bush advisers visited McCain headquarters to scrutinize his tax...

byline.original: By ALISON MITCHELL with FRANK BRUNI

docs.lead_paragraph: Fresenius Medical Care A.G., the nation's largest provider of kidney dialysis services, said yesterday that it would pay $486 million to settle federal civil and criminal fraud charges involving Medicare and other government programs. Government officials said both the civil settlement of $385 million and the $101 million in criminal fines were the largest in a five-year antifraud campaign involving blood-testing laboratories and other heath care companies.

headline.main: Dialysis Provider to Pay $486 Million to Settle Charges

docs.abstract: Fresenius Medical Care AG, nation's largest provider of kidney dialysis services, says it will pay $486 million to settle federal civil and criminal fraud charges involving Medicare and other government programs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Jan. 16 news article about Canada's overflowing hospitals suggests that the problem could be cured simply by spending more money on health care. If, like Americans, Canadians devoted 14 percent rather than 9.5 percent of their gross domestic product to health care, they could have anything Americans have in health care, and more.
docs.abstract: Letter by Uwe E Reinhardt, professor of economics at Princeton University, notes that Canadians spend less on health care than Americans and their hospital stays are much longer (Jan 16 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton proposed today to spend $110 billion over the next decade on initiatives to help at least five million people get health insurance. In so doing, he basically endorsed the approach favored by Vice President Al Gore in the Democratic debate over how best to cover the uninsured. The president said his proposals, a package of incremental steps to cover discrete groups, would be the biggest public investment in health insurance since the creation of Medicare in 1965.

headline.main: Clinton to Seek $110 Billion for Uninsured

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton proposes to spend $110 billion over next decade on initiatives to help at least five million people get health insurance, the approach basically favored by Vice Pres Al Gore in Democratic debate over how best to cover the uninsured; would expand existing programs like Medicaid and the new Children's Health Insurance Program, letting parents enroll in them with their children; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Russia Sets Date to End Its Campaign in Chechnya Lt. Gen. Gennadi Troshev said the Russian military intended to bring the campaign in Chechnya to a close by Feb. 26, which would be a month before presidential elections. The announcement came as Russian forces pressed an assault on Grozny. A12 Remaking Ulster's Police Britain said the Royal Ulster Constabulary, the militaristic police force of Northern Ireland, would be reduced in size, have its membership broadened to better reflect the population of the province and have its politically charged name retired. Conservatives in Parliament denounced the decision. A5

docs.lead_paragraph: The nation's second-largest nursing home operator filed today for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, attributing its misfortune to federal cuts in Medicare reimbursement. The Atlanta-based company, Mariner Post-Acute Network, runs more than 400 nursing homes nationwide. It said the 1997 Balanced Budget Act had cut its Medicare reimbursement by $115 for each nursing home resident.

docs.lead_paragraph: Harry and Louise, featured in television commercials that helped kill President Clinton's plan for universal health insurance in 1994, are back. They still work for the insurance industry, but now, in a new television commercial, they prod Mr. Clinton, Congress and political candidates to do something about the problem of 44 million Americans without health coverage.

headline.main: 'Harry and Louise' Return, With Health Insurance Plan

docs.abstract: Harry and Louise, characters in television commercials that helped kill Pres Clinton's plan for universal health insurance in 1994, are back working for insurance industry in new television commercial, which prods Clinton, Congress and political candidates to do something about problem of 44 million Americans who lack health coverage (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the waiting room of Dr. Mark D. Fromer's office in Trump Tower -- not so long ago filled with elderly patients seeking treatment for cataract disease -- young professionals with expensive haircuts whisper into cell phones as they wait for their 15-minute laser eye surgery appointments. Patients at the SoHo Integrative Health Center in Manhattan can see Dr. Laurie Polis, the center's dermatologist, for a routine skin cancer check, then get the wrinkles in their forehead zapped. Dr. Irwin Smigel, a prominent Manhattan dentist, passes people needing routine fillings on to his associates; he is far too busy applying the latest tooth-whitening concoction on his patients.
docs.abstract: Thousands of doctors nationwide, facing declining revenues from reimbursement cuts by managed care companies, turn to cosmetic medicine to keep practices lucrative; since nearly every elective procedure to improve appearance is not paid for by insurance companies, patients must pay often staggering sums up front, freeing doctors from problems with rejected bills, paperwork and reduced payments by managed care companies; cosmetic procedures are supplementing basic care in some practices and nearly replacing it in others; experts say elective procedures make up nearly 25 percent of many medical practices in urban areas, up from 10 percent five years ago; photos (M)
